channel.title: Tate Events
channel.description: This podcast presents highlights from Tate's wide-ranging programme of talks, symposiums and live events at all four Tate galleries.

image.title: Tate Events
image.description: British and international modern and contemporary art

channel.itunes:subtitle: Highlights from Tate's wide-ranging programme of talks, symposiums and live events at all four Tate galleries.
channel.itunes:summary: Tate hosts a wide-ranging programme of talks, symposia and live events at all four Tate galleries. This podcast presents highlights of this programme. Visit www.tate.org.uk/calendar for details of upcoming events at the galleries. To receive regular email updates on events and exhibitions, visit www.tate.org.uk/bulletins. All works in the Tate collection can be viewed at www.tate.org.uk/art. Additional information on this and other Tate podcasts can be found at www.tate.org.uk
channel.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: The Black Subject: Modernism
item.description: This symposium takes an interdisciplinary approach, exploring relationships between artists and models, multi-racial interwar communities, historical subjects, sexuality, gender and the work of previously neglected artists.
item.itunes:summary: This symposium takes an interdisciplinary approach, exploring relationships between artists and models, multi-racial interwar communities, historical subjects, sexuality, gender and the work of previously neglected artists.

item.description: A discussion with Prof. Laura Marcus (Oxford University) and writer and critic Prof. Sukhdev Sandhu (NYU), chaired by Tate Curator Sonya Dyer

item.title: BMW Tate Live: The Future of Live
item.description: The talk addresses some of the thoughts and observations emerging from the inter-disciplinary debates around the nature of the performative and live art in order to identify future trajectories for performance in this highly mediated digital age
item.itunes:summary: The talk addresses some of the thoughts and observations emerging from the inter-disciplinary debates around the nature of the performative and live art in order to identify future trajectories for performance in this highly mediated digital age

item.title: Susan Meiselas in conversation with Simon Baker
item.description: Documentary photographer Susan Meiselas, whose work features in Conflict, Time, Photography discusses her illustrious career in photojournalism with curator Simon Baker.
item.itunes:summary: Documentary photographer Susan Meiselas, whose work features in Conflict, Time, Photography discusses her illustrious career in photojournalism with curator Simon Baker.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Future Citizen Forum: Values
item.description: What is the value of being a citizen? What are the values that will or should guide the future citizen? How can we rethink the idea of value away from a purely economic model of worth?
item.itunes:summary: What is the value of being a citizen? What are the values that will or should guide the future citizen? How can we rethink the idea of value away from a purely economic model of worth?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: The landscape in contemporary photography: From the sublime to the ridiculous
item.description: Speakers are Thomas Struth, Penelope Umbrico, Massimo Vitali and Lauren Marsolier and Mishka Henner. The panel is chaired by William Ewing, Director of Curatorial Projects at Thames & Hudson.
item.itunes:summary: Speakers are Thomas Struth, Penelope Umbrico, Massimo Vitali and Lauren Marsolier and Mishka Henner. The panel is chaired by William Ewing, Director of Curatorial Projects at Thames & Hudson.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Purple and Snails: Polke's Experiments with Colour
item.description: In the early 1980s the German artist Sigmar Polke became a dedicated scholar of pigment manufacture. He favoured highly toxic, banned or otherwise exotic substances, but as a modern day alchemist he shrouded his knowledge in mystery.
item.itunes:summary: In the early 1980s the German artist Sigmar Polke became a dedicated scholar of pigment manufacture. He favoured highly toxic, banned or otherwise exotic substances, but as a modern day alchemist he shrouded his knowledge in mystery.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Artist's Talk: Ciara Phillips in conversation with Emily Pethick
item.description: Join Ciara Phillips as she discusses her collaborative projects, her Turner Prize nomination and other work with Emily Pethick, Director of The Showroom.
item.itunes:summary: Join Ciara Phillips as she discusses her collaborative projects, her Turner Prize nomination and other work with Emily Pethick, Director of The Showroom.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Radio Benjamin: Live Now
item.description: Walter Benjamin (1892–1940) is best known for his pioneering work on technology, culture and art, making enduring contributions to aesthetic theory and Western Marxism.
item.itunes:summary: Walter Benjamin (1892–1940) is best known for his pioneering work on technology, culture and art, making enduring contributions to aesthetic theory and Western Marxism.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Gregory J. Markopoulos: Film as Film
item.description: Gregory J. Markopoulos is a key figure in the history of independent film and was, alongside Kenneth Anger, Stan Brakhage, Maya Deren and Andy Warhol, a pioneer of the New American Cinema of the 1960s.
item.itunes:summary: Gregory J. Markopoulos is a key figure in the history of independent film and was, alongside Kenneth Anger, Stan Brakhage, Maya Deren and Andy Warhol, a pioneer of the New American Cinema of the 1960s.

item.title: Future of the City: Grassroots Perspectives
item.description: The discussion includes case studies from Latin America amongst other examples. Speakers include Justin McGuirk author of Radical Cities alongside Andreas Lang from public works, a London-based non-for-profit art and architecture practice.
item.itunes:summary: The discussion includes case studies from Latin America amongst other examples. Speakers include Justin McGuirk author of Radical Cities alongside Andreas Lang from public works, a London-based non-for-profit art and architecture practice.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: BMW Tate Live: On Mediated Experience: Transforming Performance
item.description: This event takes the BMW Tate Live Performance Room as illustrative of the ways in which performance is responding to a highly mediated world, where performance often comes into being simultaneously live and online.
item.itunes:summary: This event takes the BMW Tate Live Performance Room as illustrative of the ways in which performance is responding to a highly mediated world, where performance often comes into being simultaneously live and online.
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Show Time: Curating contemporary art
item.description: What are the exhibitions that truly changed the course of the discipline, provoked public reactions and contributed to a more complex understanding of what exhibition-making means today?
item.itunes:summary: What are the exhibitions that truly changed the course of the discipline, provoked public reactions and contributed to a more complex understanding of what exhibition-making means today?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Sigmar Polke: Films
item.description: Introduction to the film screening by special guests from Polke’s family who will discuss his relationship to film and Christof Kohlhöfer will also discuss his collaboration with Polke.
item.itunes:summary: Introduction to the film screening by special guests from Polke’s family who will discuss his relationship to film and Christof Kohlhöfer will also discuss his collaboration with Polke.

item.title: Sound, music, visual: producing the interdisciplinary
item.description: This half-day conference examines the motivations of artists, producers and institutions to work in the context of interdisciplinary events, and asks where is this interdisciplinary practice headed?
item.itunes:summary: This half-day conference examines the motivations of artists, producers and institutions to work in the context of interdisciplinary events, and asks where is this interdisciplinary practice headed?

item.title: Painting, Politics, Persona: What Polke Means Today?
item.description: This audio recording aims to situate Sigmar Polke's significance within a wider art historical context before unpicking the complex layers of his diverse practice, raising questions around what makes his art of such contemporary relevance today.
item.itunes:summary: This audio recording aims to situate Sigmar Polke's significance within a wider art historical context before unpicking the complex layers of his diverse practice, raising questions around what makes his art of such contemporary relevance today.

item.title: In Conversation: Wangechi Mutu
item.description: A riveting and candid conversation charting Wangechi Mutu’s career to date via her varied sources of inspiration, including her current exploration of the possibilities of printmaking, mythology and more. Audio recording.
item.itunes:summary: A riveting and candid conversation charting Wangechi Mutu’s career to date via her varied sources of inspiration, including her current exploration of the possibilities of printmaking, mythology and more. Audio recording.

item.title: Emigré Artists and their Archives: Naum Gabo and his Contemporaries - part 3
item.description: When Naum Gabo left Russia in 1922, he did not know that he would never return. Like many of his contemporaries, circumstances forced him to move from his new home in Berlin to Paris, London and Cornwall, before finally settling in the United States.
item.itunes:summary: When Naum Gabo left Russia in 1922, he did not know that he would never return. Like many of his contemporaries, circumstances forced him to move from his new home in Berlin to Paris, London and Cornwall, before finally settling in the United States.

item.title: The Endless City
item.description: Ricky Burdett, Enrique Peñalosa, Sir Richard Rogers and Deyan Sudjic discuss the book 'The Endless City', which takes six major cities as its focal point and examines the key social, structural and economic factors critical to creating a thriving city

item.description: In this audio recording Portuguese artist Julião Sarmento draws upon themes of memory, sexuality, transgression, morality and duality. He is in conversation with critic and writer Adrian Searle.

item.title: Gauguin: Curator’s Talk
item.description: Assistant curator Amy Dickson discusses how the Gauguin exhibition aspires to challenge commonly held assumptions about the artist and his practice by revealing the complexity of his narrative strategies and explore the myths central to his creativity.

item.title: Zaha Hadid and Suprematism
item.description: Considering Hadid’s concept of architecture and its relationship to space and the city, this audio recording reflects on Malevich’s Architektons, as well as other works of Suprematism, as formative inspiration for her own practice.

item.title: TV as Material 3: The Television Studio
item.description: The material structures of the TV studio, including sets, production apparatus and control rooms, provide a starting point and a setting for many contemporary artists seeking to explore television’s changing institutional architecture and culture.
item.itunes:summary: The material structures of the TV studio, including sets, production apparatus and control rooms, provide a starting point and a setting for many contemporary artists seeking to explore television’s changing institutional architecture and culture.

item.title: TV as Material 2: Broadcast Collaborations
item.description: This screening and discussion will explore how artists have collaborated with broadcasters in both the public and commercial sectors, ranging from pioneers to contemporary practitioners.

item.title: TV as Material 1: Artists and Archive at the BBC
item.description: This event showcases a diverse range of artists’ approaches both to television and the archive, including new works by Kate Davis, Kathryn Elkin, Luke Fowler, Torsten Lauschmann, Stephen Sutcliffe and Alia Syed, followed by a discussion.

item.title: Artist's talk: David Batchelor
item.description: David Batchelor’s work comprises three-dimensional structures, photographs and drawings, mostly related to a long term interest in colour and urbanism. To coincide with the Malevich exhibition, Batchelor hosts his talk The Story of the Un-Squared Square

item.description: How can performance shape our use and understanding of public space? Who is represented through public performative events? What does publicness mean in a global community?

item.description: Who do artists think they are? What myths are they rejecting and propagating? What is the social role of artists in different countries around the world today? How do artists negotiate power? Self-belief? Recognition?

item.title: Who Was Eadweard Muybridge?
item.description: Much has been written about Eadweard Muybridge’s work and accomplishments. While we know the bare facts of his life, there is little understanding of Muybridge the person.

item.title: Muybridge’s Models
item.description: Eadweard Muybridge is renowned as a pioneer photographer, scientist and inventor of the zoopraxiscope which he used to project his images to create the illusion of movement. Audio recording.
item.itunes:summary: Eadweard Muybridge is renowned as a pioneer photographer, scientist and inventor of the zoopraxiscope which he used to project his images to create the illusion of movement. Audio recording.

item.title: Projecting the Living Image
item.description: In this audio recording Leading British Muybridge scholar and specialist in the history of audio-visual media, Stephen Herbert talks about the influential photographer’s experiments with the Zoöpraxiscope, and recent research into Muybridge's 'lost years'
item.itunes:summary: In this audio recording Leading British Muybridge scholar and specialist in the history of audio-visual media, Stephen Herbert talks about the influential photographer’s experiments with the Zoöpraxiscope, and recent research into Muybridge's 'lost years'

item.title: Overlooked Victorian Artists - Reputation and Representation
item.description: Alison Smith considers Tate's original role as the custodian of modern British (Victorian) art and the challenges facing curators today in displaying and developing this part of what is now a much broader collection. Part of British Art Network project.

item.title: Overlooked Victorian Artists - The Lost Generation, 1880-1920
item.description: Professor Liz Prettejohn explores the strange critical fortunes of artists whose careers spanned the awkward divide across the year 1900 – too late to be considered typical Victorians, too early to be called modernists. Part of British Art Network project
item.itunes:summary: Professor Liz Prettejohn explores the strange critical fortunes of artists whose careers spanned the awkward divide across the year 1900 – too late to be considered typical Victorians, too early to be called modernists. Part of British Art Network project

item.title: Film screening and Q&A for Rirkrit Tiravanija: Karl Holmqvist
item.description: Often in the work of Rirkrit Tiravanija, what interests the artist is not the art in itself, but the life that unfolds around and out of it. Karl Holmqvist, whose work spans performance, poetry and fine art, is filmed as an example of a single life.

item.title: Global Citizenship: Lessons for the G8 members
item.description: What can G8 governments do to foster wider cooperation as growing numbers of the world’s population aspire to enjoy the living standards of a wealthy minority? Can they enlist the aid of other sectors of society, including business?
item.itunes:summary: What can G8 governments do to foster wider cooperation as growing numbers of the world’s population aspire to enjoy the living standards of a wealthy minority? Can they enlist the aid of other sectors of society, including business?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: After the G8 - is it going to be G-Zero or a positive number?
item.description: Humanity’s problems are global, but there is no global polity, and governance remains local and national. Is the G8 an anachronism? Is the G20 a sufficiently inclusive alternative? Who or what determines whether a nation has a voice?
item.itunes:summary: Humanity’s problems are global, but there is no global polity, and governance remains local and national. Is the G8 an anachronism? Is the G20 a sufficiently inclusive alternative? Who or what determines whether a nation has a voice?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: Capital
item.description: Money moves around the world far more freely than humans, with far less regulation and restriction. What are the repercussions of a disproportionate accumulation of wealth in the West, and the fact that the West is where most money is exchanged
item.itunes:summary: Money moves around the world far more freely than humans, with far less regulation and restriction. What are the repercussions of a disproportionate accumulation of wealth in the West, and the fact that the West is where most money is exchanged
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: Resources
item.description: Who owns the world’s natural resources? How can the riches of Africa’s minerals or Brazil’s rainforest be safely and fairly harnessed? Who can effectively change the pernicious and pervasive culture of acquisition at the expense of the environment?
item.itunes:summary: Who owns the world’s natural resources? How can the riches of Africa’s minerals or Brazil’s rainforest be safely and fairly harnessed? Who can effectively change the pernicious and pervasive culture of acquisition at the expense of the environment?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: The Forum - Expressions of Globalisation
item.description: A distinguished panel of guests discuss how the idea and the reality of globalisation are being expressed around the world. Have the languages of art and politics caught up with this phenomenon, or do we as need to find new ways to describe and own it?
item.itunes:summary: A distinguished panel of guests discuss how the idea and the reality of globalisation are being expressed around the world. Have the languages of art and politics caught up with this phenomenon, or do we as need to find new ways to describe and own it?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: Artefacts
item.description: Do the appropriation and ownership of art reflect a marketisation that mirrors the world of commerce? Does the fetishisation of artefacts perpetuate archaic definitions and perceptions of other cultures?
item.itunes:summary: Do the appropriation and ownership of art reflect a marketisation that mirrors the world of commerce? Does the fetishisation of artefacts perpetuate archaic definitions and perceptions of other cultures?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: The University
item.description: Are universities victims of globalisation, threatened by the flow of people, capital and digital information, or do they actively shape the forms that globalisation takes?
item.itunes:summary: Are universities victims of globalisation, threatened by the flow of people, capital and digital information, or do they actively shape the forms that globalisation takes?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Global Citizenship: The Foreigner - Exiles and migrants
item.description: Radical changes in patterns of human movement and displacement force us to rethink notions of migration, foreignness and identity. Do they need to be redefined to reflect these changes? If so, how and from whose perspective?
item.itunes:summary: Radical changes in patterns of human movement and displacement force us to rethink notions of migration, foreignness and identity. Do they need to be redefined to reflect these changes? If so, how and from whose perspective?
item.itunes:author: Tate

item.title: Joan Jonas in conversation with Ute Meta Bauer
item.description: Jonas will give an insight into how she creates the different stages and formats that form a body of work, focusing on her most recent project Reanimation, for which jazz pianist, Jason Moran composed the music

item.description: Tracing the sources of globalisation without the boundaries of nation or civilisation resurrects the project of universal history on new ground. In this talk Susan Buck-Morss argues it is to be excavated not across collective boundaries, but without them.

item.title: UBS Openings: The Long Weekend 2009 Italian Experimental Films from the 1960s and 70s Dissonant Dandy: Luigi Ontani - Intro and Q&A
item.description: Luigi Ontani came to prominence in Italy and internationally during the late 1960s and 70s with a series of performances and exhibitions. His dandy persona was deployed to re-enact 'tableaux vivants' from folklore, fairy tales, mythology, art and history.

item.title: Polish New Wave: Andrzej Żuławski - On the Silver Globe - Intro and Q&A
item.description: One of the earliest cosmic odysseys and science fiction superproductions, the film begins and ends with off-screen commentary by Żuławski on the failure of the film's twelve-year-long production, left unfinished due to bureaucratic intervention.

item.title: Contemporary Painting and History Symposium
item.description: How can artists find inspiration from modernist history and the more recent past? In what ways is contemporary painting negotiating the boundaries of its discipline? What is contemporary painting's attitude to theory?

item.title: John Peacock: What Makes an Aristocrat?
item.description: Van Dyck's portraits of nobility appear to represent their sitters as superior beings, 'naturally' entitled to the pre-eminence which they enjoyed. This entitlement, through lineage or genetic inheritance, was vigorously questioned during the 16th century
item.itunes:summary: Van Dyck's portraits of nobility appear to represent their sitters as superior beings, 'naturally' entitled to the pre-eminence which they enjoyed. This entitlement, through lineage or genetic inheritance, was vigorously questioned during the 16th century

item.description: Nicolas Bourriaud describes a 'new type of form…a wandering, rather than a fixed space-time', mirrored by the current emphasis on online content for museums and galleries. Miltos Manetas discusses the possibility and place for non-static, non-spatial art

item.title: Civilisation: The Value of Art
item.description: This discussion will be deconstructing artistic value forty years since Lord Clark’s Civilisation. Clark assumes a connoisseur model of valuing art which contrasts with the subjective altermodern approach to appreciating art.

item.description: The Altermodern Manifesto suggests today's artists are responding to a 'new globalised perception', moving away from art generated by personal identity. Yara El-Sherbini uses popular culture and humour to explore these shifting areas of art practice

item.title: 'A Carelesse Romance': Fashion and Fantasy in van Dyck's Portraits of the English Court
item.description: As court painter, Anthony van Dyck was largely responsible for creating the glamorous image that surrounds the court of King Charles I. Aileen Ribeiro discusses the ways in which van Dyck used fashion and fantasy to evoke a mythical romantic world.

item.description: Audio recordings of a past event at Tate modern, seeking to map Mumbai, examining the role that the arts and culture have played in the regeneration of the city.

item.title: M/M (Paris) Talk
item.description: M/M speak about their practice and collaborations, and their position between the art and design worlds with Alice Rawsthorn, design critic of the International Herald Tribune.
